author: Deleted User
content: if the blocksize is increased 25% will the fees go down 25%?

author: sky.cactus
content: Unlikely, but no way to know for sure.

author: Deleted User
content: a blocksize increase might reduce the time it takes to reach low fees but they wont get low overnight then. this assumes everything else stays equal tho. because a blocksize increase could induce demand and creates even more 'traffic' ü§î

author: sky.cactus
content: We don't have any idea what the latent demand is just below the current base fee.  It is possible that should more space become available it will immediately be gobbled up by the latest demand.

author: treyzania
content: google "induced demand"

author: Deleted User
content: i guess you just did that

author: Deleted User
content: Its quick to raise the price but slow to lower it and it seems to settle around twice the price the fee was before the spike :/

author: pietjepuk
content: you're quick to judge that the spike has ended, I see shittons of pending transactions to that The Sevens thing still

author: Deleted User
content: imo the spike ends once the priority fee is no longer bonkers. it was obviously some new launch of something!

author: pietjepuk
content: So you would say that anything that results in ~60% full blocks for sustained periods of time (minutes), pushing up the base fee to insane heights, but never actually reaching doubly full blocks that need tips, is not a spike?

author: pietjepuk
content: Here's a block that according to you should not have any NFT sale transactions in it anymore because it sold out: https://etherscan.io/txs?block=13180436, or a bit later if you think that was too soon https://etherscan.io/txs?block=13180453

author: Deleted User
content: seems like the transactions are reverted

author: pietjepuk
content: well yes, but the transactions don't just disappear. People submitted them, they still need to pay for it

author: pietjepuk
content: Or are you saying that those transactions should be discarded for some weird reason, and that the blocks can then be filled with transactions that do not revert resulting in a quick drop in base fee

author: Deleted User
content: so there can still be an on going spike even if basefee has been trending down for blocks

author: pietjepuk
content: That was my definition yes, but feel free to have a different one

author: Deleted User
content: its actually cruel how slow it is to adjust down for people who have to pay reverted gas

author: pietjepuk
content: How is it cruel? They were willing to pay that amount no?

author: pietjepuk
content: There is just a huge backlog of transactions that didn't get in when the sale ended. Those transactions still need to be processed, and that's what most of that ramp down is.

author: Deleted User
content: maybe they are saving money..

author: pietjepuk
content: Many of those "backlog" transactions were willing to still pay a huge amount, they just didn't set a a big enough minerFeePerGas to be included in one of those first blocks of the spike. It's basically pre-EIP1559 first-price auctions all over again with doubly full blocks. Except that the base fee adapts much more quickly than the oracles did at the time, because at least now we can better separate the "I want to be included the next block!" from the "Include me please".

author: Deleted User
content: i wonder if reverse MEV is a thing. Ie. DONT INCLUDE MY TRANSACTION until basefee is x

author: pietjepuk
content: Well, you can certainly code something like that now lol

author: Deleted User
content: for the guy who bid 1500 base fee but ended up getting reverted

author: pietjepuk
content: Yeah, it sucks, but pre-EIP1559 it would've been even worse for them. Because at least they now they get the difference in maxFeePerGas - baseFeePerGas back.

author: Deleted User
content: im starting to realise that üôÇ

author: pietjepuk
content: I'm probably missing a miner fee in that calculation somewhere, but I'm tired ;0

author: pietjepuk
content:
It's not a lot better though, because the base fee tends to be close to the max fee for those backlog reverted transactions. That's the reason we have that slope downward to begin with. Looking at some of those failed transactions you see a maxFeePerGas of 1500 Gwei, and a max priority feel of 1.5 Gwei lol. 

https://etherscan.io/tx/0xe87a7a532cb4a54ea6df35e7fd813c126d7e11d2f05be3f417ed0e34815b7f59

author: Deleted User
content: that is very strange they only give 1.5 tip on a high prio transction. i wonder if they replaced the transaction with a lower tip so as to get included later when basefee is likely lower because they knew their transaction was reverted and no longer worth a 1500 base fee

author: pietjepuk
content: It is very strange indeed. If it were me, I would put maxFeePerGas = maxPriorityFeePerGas = 1500, and hope for the best

author: pietjepuk
content: Of the transactions that succeeded (I think the last block where this happened is https://etherscan.io/txs?block=13180431 ), I see quite a few of those `maxFeePerGas = maxPriorityFeePerGas = 7000` (or some other high number). And someone that had 7000 and 5000 respectively. Guess that's what it took this time around to get in üòê
